original: Advancements in microscopy have led to the identification of algae within the structure of lichens, prompting a reevaluation of their biological relationships. Initially, the presence of algae was attributed to contamination, as samples were often collected in damp conditions. Consequently, these algae were not recognized as being in a symbiotic relationship with the fungal component of the thallus. However, the continued multiplication
sampled: Advancements in micro have led to the identification of algae within the structure of lichens, motivating an reevaluation of their biological relationships. Initially, the presence of algae was classified to contamination, as samples were often collected inside sticky conditions. Consequently, these algae were not recognized as being in a allied cooperation with the fungal component among the thallus. However, the continued multiplication
